pros: The UUP union was exceptional.  The department was very welcoming and supportive of their adjuncts.  Even though I was only needed for the fall semester, I felt like I belonged.  The salary listed was for 2 courses in the fall semester.
cons: Introductory courses have a very large attendance without a teaching or grading assistant.  For an adjunct, grading 90-120 homework assignments, exams, and papers per course can sometimes means your hours to income ratio puts you below minimum wage.  It's not fair to students or instructors to make adjunct choose between underpayment per hour or skimping on providing the best education possible.

review_title: My colleagues were ultimate professionals, and my experience there was a tremendous learning experience.
job_title: Held Several Titles Over A Period of Years in Middletown, NY
pros:
• Teachers, no matter how seemingly "over-qualified," are dedicated to teaching, more than research.
• Every employee, from maintenance on up, is committed to student success.
• Every alum has wonderful memories and attributes their college experience to their own success.
• The employee-to-employee atmosphere is helpful and friendly.
cons:
• At the time I worked there (I resigned in 2006) there was some unfortunate biases among the top management. 
• There was, at the time I worked there, a gender bias (in favor of men) in salary and compensation.

pros: My college is accredited by CIDA, very tight knit, and heavily focused on the education and needs of each individual student. I have learned and continue to learn eons from my department and school- reaching for opportunities and my future dreams with their assistance. #greatidear
cons: The only true con is that I wish their were more full-time staff members; a tight knit department comes with the con of being small.

pros: The student atmosphere is encouraging and the library is at the tips of your fingers.
cons: The college writing program use to pay employees $15 per hour, but recently laid off all the workers and forced teachers to work in the writing center and the time worked is calculated as a "class". Teachers that are part one that were making $15 an hour PLUS teaching up to 3 classes were able to make a decent living. Now, they are forced into an even lower level of poverty while tuition rates are increasing and administration is making significant amounts of money.

review_title: A good place to be an adjunct
pros: Students were engaged and wanted to get the most out of the courses that I taught. I worked with a special cohort; thus, I had a chance to teach many of the same students twice, in 2 different courses.
cons: Since students worked full-time, elsewhere, throughout the day, as I did, they often arrived late because the parking situation is very challenging.

review_title: It's Okay, Great Place to Work if You Care About Stability and not Personal Growth
pros:
- great people
- vacation and sick days plus comp time are great
- they care a lot about the students
cons:
- those who are permanent are close-minded to new ideas, live up to the whole "if it's not broke, don't fix it"
- really slow in getting things done
- the students don't care to be there
- everyone is confused

pros: Great students who know the value of an education. Generally good staff. Better treatment of adjunct faculty in some areas than many private colleges (for example, SUNY offers adjunct faculty health insurance)
cons: Low pay, constant fiscal difficulties, poor communication in HR matters (health insurance provider keeps getting switched with little or no notification)

pros: Thanks to UUP, BSC provides full benefits to adjuncts teaching 6 credit hours or more. If you have had to take a job just because you needed to provide your family with health insurance, and not because you loved the work, then you understand just how much more we can focus on students once our family is covered.
cons: BSC has always been a place for me to learn and grow.

pros: Current technology, Is constantly growing and getting larger. Off on holidays , right near the center of the city so close to everything.
cons: No overtime, management is hit or miss. Pay increases are almost non existent, expect at most a 2% raise a year max, and most of the time nothing. Also you start at minimum wage.

job_title: Lead Programmer Analyst in Buffalo, NY
pros: Wonderful staff and colleagues, weekly assessments to review progress, treated with respect and loyalty. A wonderful place to work if you like working with computers and inputting data. (Which I do).
cons: The only con is that I had to leave! I had my son and had to become a stay-at-home mother while his father worked. I am now ready to rejoin to the workforce.

review_title: So much potential wasted via risk-aversion and "state worker" mentality.
job_title: Learning Management Systems Administrator in Albany, NY
pros: Once you get tenure (7 years) you basically have to commit a crime to be fired.  Decent benefits (except vision).  Lots of movement potential across the university.
cons: Surrounded by people with punch card mentality.  Slow, grinding bureaucracy.  Lots of micro-managers.  Spineless union caves to governor every fiscal year and salary increases are non-existent.  Completely different expectations depending on who you report to.

review_title: I had some really positive experiences...management is myopic.
pros: EXCELLENT New York State Benefits
cons: Tenured faculty is littered with pampered, lazy, and ineffective individuals who do not have the slightest clue of what life is like outside of academia.  Organization survives off the backs of PT faculty who are pressured/coerced into added workloads.

review_title: It was an incredible time working at WBNY
pros: Everyone is friendly, it allows you to do what you want and live out your dreams. It's laid back yet strict at the same time meaning you have lots of fun but everything is professional.
cons: Space fills up quickly on the radio so you need to get in your time slot right away or you'll be doing your show early or late at night.

pros: Awesome benefits, vacation, sick, cushy job overall.
cons: Limited upward mobility, kind of boring work culture.

review_title: Great place to learn about the higher education industry!
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Great working environment. I encourage everyone to gain experience with people who actually believe in you and want you to succeed! My experience for SUNY has been great!
cons: Working for a state or government institution does not pay as much as the private sector, but have some pride that you are playing an important role in the education of your statesmen!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Perks, PTO, Ability to Move up, Availability of upper level management to resolve conflicts among employees.  Gives those of us who aren't as high up confidence
cons: Salary, beaurocracy can make inefficiences readily apparent and difficult to correct.  Wish there was more opportunity to streamlines efforts between different divisions so we can focus on what is really important

job_title: Computer Lab Tech in Albany, NY
pros: The computer lab is a more or less positive place. There are good days & bad days, just like any place of employment where you interface with many people per day.
cons: There are times when you encounter problems with technology & also the clients of the lab.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Cortland, NY
pros: I enjoyed working in the library at SUNY Cortland.  The staff were friendly and helpful.  The work environment was stress free and we were allowed to complete our homework while working.  I received training by senior staff member.  There  is opportunity to grow and gain new skills.
cons: Opportunity to work extra is usually given by favoritism.

pros: Enjoyed being depended upon for ideas as well as for the construction of many items such as websites, flash banners, forms, certificates, data analyses and graphics. Both bosses were challenging yet personable and fun to work with.
cons: The nature of this job is tough. There are strict deadlines to be met to ensure that everything is ready for the incoming students.

review_title: Administrative oversight of programs, budget, curriculum
